turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: What now?

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: We're outta here--

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: --be prepared.

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: We don't have time!

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Yeah and we don't have much ammo either!

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Let's move it we got company!

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: What happened!

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Forget about it.

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: I wasn't angry with you I was angry with him.

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: He's a very stubborn man sometimes...

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: You should listen your old man more often.  He's got principles.

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: After Leizburg, he stuck his neck out to defend me.  He's loyal to the end. Even if it's not--politically correct at the time.

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: What's that supposed to mean?

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: Let me tell you something Cooper! I never once bad-mouthed him during all those months--

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: No but you didn't defend him either! Didn't want to rock the boat.  Guess the ride was too smooth. FILMORE I was acting under legal counsel!

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: Cooper...

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Yeah?...

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: I drew my gun, ran in the direction of the cries...violating the first rule of service...I let the Ambass- ador out of my sight.

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: By the time I got back to the party our ambassador was face-down, in a bed of bloody azaleas.

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: You're a lot like my father, Cooper... you think with your heart.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Used to Filmore, used to.

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: Now what?

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: There's the fence...

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: I'm going first.  Taking the fire. If we go out together we're all dead!

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: They probably have guards on the roof--and they're gonna be firing at me--not you! ATKINS What makes you so sure?

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Because I'll be firing at them.

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: You're talking about committing suicide!

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: What about rule one:  never let the person you are protecting out of your sight!

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Rule two:  without alternative, use yourself as a shield.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Well Filmore--

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: Well Cooper...

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Looks like you're not going to make that dinner after all...

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: I guess not Cooper...

turns.speaker: OLO
turns.text: I have a lighter!

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Even better.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: How well do you know this place?

turns.speaker: OLO
turns.text: We're on sublevel six.  We'll pass some labs and then we'll hit the stairwell--

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Are the labs in operation?

turns.speaker: OLO
turns.text: I don't see why they wouldn't be.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Good...

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: How's the arm?

turns.speaker: OLO
turns.text: It's nothing to worry about.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: We wouldn't have made it out without you. FILMORE Or without you.

turns.speaker: OLO
turns.text: That's it!  Up ahead!

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Where does it lead?

turns.speaker: OLO
turns.text: The maintenance hatch--it takes us outside the building!

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Enjoying the tour so far?

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: Are you going to kill us?

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: I don't know.  If you gave me a reason to...

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: Go fuck yourself...

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Hey now!  No cussing on TV!  Well in closing I'd like to say that there are two reasons to have that money outside in an hour.  One is my perky co-anchor here, and the second is the lives of tens of thousands of people--people just like you and me!

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: I hope you don't mind all this--it's just that the networks will eat it up, you know...

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: You're going to pay for this...

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: You got it all backwards, Helen--but that's OK, you work for the government...

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: You understand that they're watching our every move right now--you think you're just going to sail away?

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: It seems to me we are just sailing away. They haven't sunk us yet, have they? Besides, don't you worry your pretty little head about that.  It's all been taken care of.

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: I know you're not too happy at this point.  It's too bad we weren't able to meet elsewhere, under different circumstances...

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: Like where--in your dreams?

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: I suppose...you think I should thank you.

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Yes, you should.

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: You see, it paid off--you broke away from the old guard, congresswoman.  It won't be long till they're calling you Senator Filmore--

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: Shut up!

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Come on, drink up.

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: I don't want any...

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: I insist...

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: I said I don't want any, goddammit!

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: Came over the satellite.  We're keeping the bird clear should they call back.

turns.speaker: SEN. FILMORE
turns.text: She's still alive.

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: The transmission is an hour old...

turns.speaker: SEN. FILMORE
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: We've prohibited the networks from broadcasting the transmissions.

turns.speaker: SEN. FILMORE
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: We have a special forces squadron out of Thailand surrounding the compound as we speak.

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: Why the hell didn't you tell us this was at stake!

turns.speaker: SEN. FILMORE
turns.text: Chemco's been developing nerve gas?

turns.speaker: SEN. FILMORE
turns.text: What about Cooper--where is he?

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: He's in there...

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: Looks like Richter isn't acting alone--he's heading into some dangerous waters.

turns.speaker: SEN. FILMORE
turns.text: She's as good as gone...

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: You can't think like that!  We're watching them like a hawk--he's bound to trip up, make one false move--

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: This was taken when Richter was arrested in Washington state, 1985. He was charged with interstate arms trafficking, skipped bail, and has since been a fugitive.

turns.speaker: WHITE
turns.text: Chemco is willing to deal with him, meet his demands.  I can have the money there in an hour.

turns.speaker: WHITE
turns.text: And--of course there is the human cost, which is incalculable.

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: I'm sure you'll figure it out.

turns.speaker: WHITE
turns.text: Who's Ryan Cooper?

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: I'll let the senator tell you.

turns.speaker: WHITE
turns.text: And what exactly do they intend to do?

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: The ball is in Richter's court.  But we're sure as hell not going to sit on our hands while he assassinates people--we're gonna stop the son-of- a-bitch!

turns.speaker: WHITE
turns.text: I don't think you--grasp--the situation, Mr. Myers.

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: So, what are we looking at White?

turns.speaker: WHITE
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: What do they have in there that's so valuable?  A cure for AIDS, a cure for cancer?

turns.speaker: WHITE
turns.text: I assure you gentlemen if we had something of that magnitude it wouldn't be shelved in a lab somewhere...

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: Is there anything in there that can blow?  We have to be ready for any contingency--

turns.speaker: WHITE
turns.text: Mister Myers it is a chemical plant! There are a number of volatile compounds-- but they are safely stored away...

turns.speaker: WHITE
turns.text: Chemco makes many things senator! We were under government contract!

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: I haven't been briefed on any such thing!

turns.speaker: WHITE
turns.text: Apparently, this project is--unique. But it's heavily protected--all formulas are heavily codified!

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: What the hell is it, anyhow?

turns.speaker: WHITE
turns.text: Well, it's a binary formula--a precise amount of two separate chemicals must be exposed to the nitrogen in the atmosphere simultaneously for it to work.

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: How much do they have?

turns.speaker: WHITE
turns.text: He wouldn't take it on the helicopters. He'd transport it through pipelines that connect Chemco to the waterfront...

turns.speaker: MYERS
turns.text: What!

turns.speaker: WHITE
turns.text: They were probably topping off a docked tanker while he stalled for time--without anyone being the wiser...

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: How goes the roll call?

turns.speaker: SMITTY
turns.text: We're secured.  Takeover team is in position and accounted for.

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Have you broken it yet?  We've got six more heads and that means six more hours.

turns.speaker: SMITTY
turns.text: I'm in to the directory but they've codified the stockpile--numerically.

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Of course it's codified!  Each number probably corresponds to a compound.  Have them pull every compound from the lab and compare it to the codes till you figure it out--that's what you're here for.

turns.speaker: SMITTY
turns.text: I know what I'm here for-you don't need to remind me.

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Something tells me you don't want to be on TV, friend.

turns.speaker: SMITTY
turns.text: Richter-we got a problem!

turns.speaker: SMITTY
turns.text: KZ...7-0...7-0...nine.  It checks out.

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Excellent...excellent!

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Where the hell could they have gone!

turns.speaker: SMITTY
turns.text: What are you so worked up about jack? Fuck 'em--we don't need 'em.

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: I want the girl.  I don't care about the rest--but a US congresswoman taken hostage will make for great copy. We'll make headlines all over the world...

turns.speaker: SMITTY
turns.text: You're fucking crazy Richter--you know that?

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: What's happening at the waterfront?

turns.speaker: SMITTY
turns.text: We're almost done piping in directly to the Olympia.  Should have it all in about an hour or so.

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Excellent.

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Our traveler's insurance, you know what I mean?

turns.speaker: STOCKTON
turns.text: Gotcha.  We've been filling barrels all day--we've got  hell of a stockpile.

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: STOCKTON
turns.text: I say we head out.

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Agreed--let's move it.

turns.speaker: STOCKTON
turns.text: Are you hungry?  We can discuss some final arrangements over some slop in the galley.

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Captain it would be impossible to turn down such a gracious request.

turns.speaker: STOCKTON
turns.text: My crew is going to work alongside with your men, don't worry--we're a team!

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Why should I worry?  Is there a problem?

turns.speaker: STOCKTON
turns.text: Well, there was uh, a little dissent about the amount of the bonus--

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Dissent?

turns.speaker: STOCKTON
turns.text: You know, when we reach Kompong Som--

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Are we adrift--

turns.speaker: STOCKTON
turns.text: If I don't get power up we are!

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Drop the anchor!

turns.speaker: STOCKTON
turns.text: We can't--it's power driven!

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Get your men to do it!

turns.speaker: STOCKTON
turns.text: The thing weighs more than a ton-- you want to roll up your sleeves and try it?!

turns.speaker: SEN. FILMORE
turns.text: Just what the hell is he talking about?

turns.speaker: WHITE
turns.text: We've...been developing a product... KZ 70709.

turns.speaker: WHITE
turns.text: Of the separate chemicals--I don't know, uh, offhand--

turns.speaker: SEN. FILMORE
turns.text: How much of this shit do they have, White!!

turns.speaker: WHITE
turns.text: They must have got their hands on a test vial!

turns.speaker: SEN. FILMORE
turns.text: What does that mean?

turns.speaker: WHITE
turns.text: There's enough in one vial...

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Please be calm, Ambassador De Sade.

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: You will not get away with this vicious attack on our peace-loving people.

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: War-mongering bully!  Don't think you're going to intimidate me!

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: All right, Mister Ambassador!  But you must treat General "Buck" Schmuck with the respect due him.

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: Can I have a glass of water?

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Certainly - how about some breakfast?

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: Possibly some coffee?

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Moffo!

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: Thank you, Admiral.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Now, Mister Ambassador.  In a very few moments we should have Premier Belch on the phone.  I intend to tell him exactly what has happened.  I merely want you to authenticate certain facts for him.

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: The food - you wouldn't put - anything in it, would you?

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Don't be ridiculous.

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: I have your word, Mister President?

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Yes, of course.

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: Where are you trying to reach him?

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: At his office in the Capitol.

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: If he's not there, try...  87 - 43 - 56.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Did you get that, Kulnick?

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: What's the meaning of this?

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: I am sorry.  Sub-miniature photography is my hobby.  It's amazing what excellent en- largements you can make from the negative.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: I'll hold this, if you don't mind.  You can have it back when you leave.

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: Well, it has been explained to me that, if you add a thick Cobalt-Thorium-G jacket to a nuclear device, the radio- activity resulting from such a nuclear explosion will retain its lethal power for a hundred years.

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: Our scientists calculated that the detonation of fifty of our biggest nuclear devices, jacketed in Cobalt-Thorium-G would enshroud the earth in a hundred years of lethal radio- activity from which no human life could escape. In ten months the Earth would be as dead as the Moon.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Where is this...thing?

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: It is buried somewhere in the Grudd Mountains.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Mister Ambassador, what on earth possessed your country to build this weapon?

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: First of all, economic reasons.  It was cheap.  The entire project cost just a fraction of what we spent in a single year on our various space and missile programs. It also seemed ideal in most other respects. It was terrifying, convincing, automatic, and extremely simple to understand.

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: But, finally, one factor tipped the scales. We received information from a very re- liable source that your country was going to build one.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: That's preposterous!  We have no such program!

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: The source was...shall we say, completely reliable.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: The report is entirely untrue.  I can assure you of that.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: Allow me to assure you that my government will not be satisfied with a polite note of regret for this shocking example of aggression against our peace-loving people.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Damn you, de Sade!  You know as well as I do that this was the act of a mentally sick man - a single individual, whose crack-up can probably be traced to the strains and tensions caused by your country.

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: It is very convenient to place all the blame on a dead man.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: How dare you talk to me in this manner?

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: This dreadful accident could never have happened if your government hadn't cynically and hypocritic- ally blocked every proposal we made for disarmament or arms control!!

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: Bah!  All you wanted to do was spy in our country!

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: That's nonsense, and you know it!

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: I know nothing of the sort!

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Surely, you don't expect us to destroy our weapons without being able to verify that you are doing the same?

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: And surely you don't expect us to let you spy in our country before you destroy your weapons.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Don't you realize that despite your incredible distrust and suspicion, that in fact, you place a far greater trust in us than inspection would require?  You trust us not to cause a war accidentally - and, of course, we are obliged to place the same trust in you.

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: And now, Mister President, I must return at once to my embassy to communicate this reassuring news to the Premier.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Goodbye, Mister Ambassador.

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: We have many splendidly deep mines in our country.

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: Excuse me, Mister President, but you forgot to give me my camera back.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Oh, yes, that's right.

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: Premier Belch will not be fooled by this fantastic lie.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Mister President, are you going to let this stooge talk to you like this?

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: Don't you dare touch me!  What the devil do you think you're doing?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: I caught you red-handed, Mister Ambassador.

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: Give that back to me.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: What do you think of this, Mister President?  I told you we shouldn't let him in here.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Do you mean to say you'd set it off in your own country?

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: Naturally.  It would kill us just as surely even if we set it off in your country.  But this way we know it's safe, and we don't have the problem of delivering it.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Mister President, I can't buy this malarkey; they wouldn't set the damn thing off.  Why should they?

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: You're absolutely right.  We wouldn't.  No sane nation ever would.  That's why it was designed to trigger itself automatically.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Then all you have to do is untrigger it.

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: Ah, but if we were able to untrigger it, that would be defeating its purpose.  All our enemies would have to do, would be to warn us in advance that they were going to violate one of our unalterable triggering conditions. We would bluff, naturally, but in the end we would be insane not to untrigger it. Now we can say: There is no point trying to intimidate us, we don't control the Doomsday Machine.

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: Perhaps you gentlemen would like to check with the source?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: You mean you'll tell us his name???

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: It's not a he, General.  It was an article in the "Times" about a year and a half ago.

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: Please, Mister President, I am extremely shy and do not wish to endure this sort of personal humiliation.  Here is the only other camera I have left.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: See!  See, I told you.

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: My seven body orifices????

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: That's right, fella.

turns.speaker: AMBASSADOR DE SADE
turns.text: One, two...  three, four...  five...  Why you, dirty, stinking...

turns.speaker: COLONEL "BAT" GUANO
turns.text: Major?...Major?  I'm Colonel "Bat" Guano, 701 Battalion.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Come in...come in... Peace On Earth... Peace On Earth...yes...

turns.speaker: COLONEL "BAT" GUANO
turns.text: Why are you saying that phrase over and over again?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: I think that just might be it!  Although it could be Riki-Tiki-Tavi.

turns.speaker: COLONEL "BAT" GUANO
turns.text: What are you talking about, Major?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: The three-letter code group.  Or maybe some combination of the three letters. P...O...E, or P...E...O, or E...O...P... let's see, there would be six possible combinations.

turns.speaker: COLONEL "BAT" GUANO
turns.text: Get a grip on yourself, Major!

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: It might still be worth trying Riki-Tiki- Tavi.  R...T...T...There's only three combinations of -- T...T...R, or T...R...T...

turns.speaker: COLONEL "BAT" GUANO
turns.text: Now, snap out of it, fella!

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Who the hell do you think you are, sir???

turns.speaker: COLONEL GUANO
turns.text: I did that for your own good, fella.  Now I'm not going to pull rank on you.  When this is over, I'll be happy to step outside with you and settle this thing.  Right now my orders are to locate General Ripper and put him on the phone with the President.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Well, you can't do that because he's dead.

turns.speaker: COLONEL GUANO
turns.text: Do you have any witnesses, Major?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: COLONEL GUANO
turns.text: What happened, Major?  Some kind of private beef between the two of you?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Look, I didn't shoot him!

turns.speaker: COLONEL GUANO
turns.text: We'll have to leave that up to the C.I.D. boys, won't we, Major?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Look, Colonel.  I've got to talk to somebody at Air Command.

turns.speaker: COLONEL GUANO
turns.text: Don't worry, Major.  Your rights will be fully protected.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Colonel, don't you know what's going on?

turns.speaker: COLONEL GUANO
turns.text: Sure I do.  There was some kind of mutiny on the base, and you killed General Ripper.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Look, General Ripper went off his rocker and ordered the 843rd Bomb Wing to attack with H-bombs.

turns.speaker: COLONEL GUANO
turns.text: You must think I'm an awful sap, Major.  Just sit down, fella, and keep your hands on the desk!

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Didn't they tell you?

turns.speaker: COLONEL GUANO
turns.text: They told me, Major.  And I didn't hear anything about any atomic attack.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Look, Colonel.  You keep me covered, but let me just pick up this red telephone that connects to Air Command headquarters. Okay?...I won't play any tricks on you... Okay?

turns.speaker: COLONEL GUANO
turns.text: Okay, fella.  But just move slow and don't do anything that might surprise me.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Sure...sure, Colonel.  Now look, I'm picking up the phone...nice and slow.  Right?...Hello? ...Hello?  Hello?...Hello?...Gee, it must be edad. Probably the lines were hit during the fighting.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Now look, I'm picking up this ordinary telephone.  See?...Hello?...Hello?... Nuts, the lines must still be disconnected.  The General had us disconnect...

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Look, Colonel.  Maybe it's too late. Maybe they've sent Air Command in already.  But we've got to try to con- tact somebody.

turns.speaker: COLONEL GUANO
turns.text: On your feet, fella.  I've got to get outside and see how my men are.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Okay, Colonel.  But look, there's a pay phone just outside in the hall.  Maybe that works, huh?  Maybe it'll work?  What do you think?

turns.speaker: COLONEL GUANO
turns.text: You've wasted enough of my time, fella.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Wait a minute.  The President!!  That's it! The President!!!

turns.speaker: COLONEL GUANO
turns.text: What about the President?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: He wanted to talk to General Ripper, didn't he?

turns.speaker: COLONEL GUANO
turns.text: So what?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Well, I'm General Ripper's Executive officer. He'll want to talk to me.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Operator...How much would the call be station-to-station?...Thirty-five cents cheaper?...I'd still be short twenty cents ...Just a second, operator...  Colonel, shoot the lock off the Coke machine.  There's bound to be enough change in there.

turns.speaker: COLONEL GUANO
turns.text: That's government property, Major.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Colonel, remember, a reprimand from the President can be pretty serious to a career officer...Just a second, operator, I know I have it somewhere.

turns.speaker: SWITCHBOARD OPERATOR
turns.text: I'm sorry, sir.  General Schmuck is asleep and he isn't taking calls until eight-thirty.

turns.speaker: COLONEL PUNTRICH
turns.text: What is your name, young lady?

turns.speaker: SWITCHBOARD OPERATOR
turns.text: Ceida Pietraszkiewicz.

turns.speaker: COLONEL PUNTRICH
turns.text: What did you say?

turns.speaker: SWITCHBOARD OPERATOR
turns.text: Ceida Pietraszkiewicz...P...I...E... T...R...A...S...Z...K...I...E...W... I...C...Z.

turns.speaker: COLONEL PUNTRICH
turns.text: Now look here, Miss Pietraszkiewicz, this is Air Command Headquarters calling.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Yes!

turns.speaker: COLONEL PUNTRICH
turns.text: General Schmuck?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Yes!  Who the hell is this?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Go back to sleep, baby.

turns.speaker: COLONEL PUNTRICH
turns.text: What did you say, sir?

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: I didn't say anything.  What's the meaning of disturbing me at this hour, Colonel?

turns.speaker: COLONEL PUNTRICH
turns.text: General Schmuck, we monitored a trans- mission about six minutes ago from Burpelson Air Force Base, HQ 843rd Wing.  It was apparently directed to their Wing on air- borne alert.  It decoded as - Wing attack, Plan-R.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Colonel, you're not drunk, are you, man?

turns.speaker: COLONEL PUNTRICH
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Then why bother me with this nonsense? Get in touch with the base commander.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Well, that's ridiculous.  If the teleprinter and radio links are out of order, just pick up a phone and pay for a call.

turns.speaker: COLONEL PUNTRICH
turns.text: I know it sounds crazy, sir, but we tried, and nobody answers any of the telephones.

turns.speaker: GENERAL SCHMUCK
turns.text: Does the threat board show anything?

turns.speaker: COLONEL PUNTRICH
turns.text: Well, that's the funny part of it, too, sir.  It doesn't show a damned thing.

turns.speaker: GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK
turns.text: Well, Mister President.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: What kind of trouble?

turns.speaker: GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK
turns.text: Well, sir, about forty-six minutes ago one of my base commanders, General Jack D. Ripper, sent out attack orders to the thirty-four B-90's of the 843rd Bomb Wing, under his command.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: General Schmuck?

turns.speaker: GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK
turns.text: Yes, sir.  He issued attack orders to --

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: May I be stupid enough to inquire WHY IN HELL THE BASE COMMANDER OF THE 843d BOMB WING DID A THING LIKE THAT ???

turns.speaker: GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK
turns.text: To be perfectly honest, Mister President, we really aren't sure.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: You aren't sure!

turns.speaker: GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK
turns.text: Not exactly, sir.  You see, Colonel Puntrich at Air Command HQ received a call from him about twenty minutes ago.  He asked General Ripper if he had issued the Go-code and the attack order, and General Ripper said:  "Sure, the orders came from me.  They're on their way in, and I advise you to get the rest of Air Command in after them. My boys will give you the best kind of start, and you sure as hell won't stop them now."  Then he hung up.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Damn it!  Damn it!  I've been telling you all for years you've got too damned many psychoes in the service.

turns.speaker: GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK
turns.text: Be fair, Mister President.  Didn't we initiate the Human Reliability tests for all personnel handling nuclear weapons?

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Buck, when I told you to give them right up to the top, you said we couldn't insult a general officer by asking him to pass a test to see if he's a psycho.

turns.speaker: GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK
turns.text: Just a second, sir.  He's got films of the War Room in that thing!

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: I'm afraid I'll have to ask you to take the film out.

turns.speaker: GENERAL FACEMAN
turns.text: Yes, sir.  One thing, Mister President.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: GENERAL FACEMAN
turns.text: Under a condition red alert, the base will probably be sealed off and defended by the base security troops.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: I am aware of what a condition red alert implies.

turns.speaker: GENERAL FACEMAN
turns.text: Well, sir, they may not allow the Special Service troops to enter the base.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: That's a very wise deduction, General.

turns.speaker: GENERAL FACEMAN
turns.text: Thank you, sir.  But what shall I tell them to do if they are denied entrance?

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: Under the circumstances, General, what would you think they should do?

turns.speaker: GENERAL FACEMAN
turns.text: Well...I suppose penetrate the base by force.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: You see, you knew the answer all the time, General.

turns.speaker: GENERAL FACEMAN
turns.text: But that would mean some of our own boys will get hurt, Mister President.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: What do you suppose is going to happen if General Ripper's planes start bombing their targets?

turns.speaker: GENERAL FACEMAN
turns.text: That certainly would be a problem, sir.

turns.speaker: GENERAL FACEMAN
turns.text: I didn't speak to him, sir.  But Colonel "Bat" Guano was in command of the Special Service battalion, so I would imagine he did.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT MUFFLEY
turns.text: I want him upped to Brigadier General, and recomended for the D.S.C.

turns.speaker: GENERAL FACEMAN
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Combat Operations Center, Major Mandrake speaking.

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: This is General Ripper speaking.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: Do you recognize my voice?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Certainly, General.  Why do you ask, sir?

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: Why do you think I ask?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: I don't know, sir. We just spoke a few minutes ago.

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: Youddon't think I'd ask if you recognized my voice unless it was important, do you, Major?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: Good.  Has the Wing confirmed holding at X-points?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: All right, Major.  I'm putting the base on condition Red.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Condition Red!

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: That's right.  I want this flashed to all section immediately.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Yes, sir.  What's up, General Ripper?

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: You're a good officer, Major Mandrake.  You have a right to know.  It looks like we're in a shooting war!

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: A shooting war!

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: Yes, Major.  This looks like it's going to be it.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: But...what kind of a shooting war?  Have they hit any of our cities yet?

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: Major, that's all I've been told.  Just got it on the red phone.  The base is to be sealed tight.  And I mean tight.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: Let me worry about that, Major. I've still got my red line to the Air Command.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: That's right, sir.

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: We don't want to be vulnerable to saboteurs calling up and pretending to be different people from the President down, do we?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: You're right, sir.

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: No calls from inside out.  No calls from outside in are even answered.  No calls.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: I understand, sir.  Nothing comes or goes without your personal say-so.

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: No calls at all.  With or without my say-so. My voice can be imitated too, Major.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Yes, sir.  I just thought of something, sir.  How do I know I'm talking to you now?

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: Who do you think you're talking to?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: To you, sir.  But how do I know?

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: Are you trying to be insubordinate?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: I hope not.  Now, as soon as you do what I told you, have Plan-R radioed to the Wing.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Plan-R????

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: Are you hard of hearing, Major?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: No, sir.  Plan-R to be radioed to the Wing.

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: As soon as you've done that, shut down the communications center.  Lock it up and assign the personnel to base security details.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: General Ripper, if I shut down the communi- cations center, there'll be no radio or teleprinter contact with Air Command head- quarters or anyone, for that matter.

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: Are you questioning my orders, Major?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: No, sir.  I'm just bringing the facts to your attention, sir.

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: You're a good officer, Major, and you're perfectly right to bring these facts to my attention.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Thank you, sir.

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: Now, as soon as you've done that, double- up on all base security teams.  Our enemies are plenty smart, and there might even be an attack on the base by saboteurs.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER
turns.text: And lastly, all privately owned radios are to be immediately impounded.  They can be used to issue instructions to saboteurs. Air Police will have lists of all owners.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: What's the gun for, General Ripper?

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Please don't take any notice of this weapon, Major.  I love all weapons, and as of late, I've just taken to keeping a loaded weapon nearby at all times.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Sort of like a new hobby, huh, General?

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: That's right, Major.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: I see you're playing your radio, Major. Isn't that contrary to my instructions for the personnel of this base?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Oh, it's not my radio, sir.  I picked it up in the communications center.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: I didn't mean for anyone to play anyone else's radio either, Major.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Yes, sir.  General, can I ask a question?

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Certainly, Major Mandrake.  You're a good officer, and you can ask me a question any time you want to.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Well, General Ripper, sir -- I was thinking -- we're on a condition red, aren't we?

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: That is correct, Major.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: And a condition red means enemy attack in progress, doesn't it?

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: You know the regulations well, Major.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Well, sir, I was thinking, if an enemy attack is in progress, how come the radio's still playing music?  It's supposed to go off, and all we should hear are Civil Defense broadcasts.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: That's a good question, Major.  Maybe if you think hard, you can think of the answer yourself.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: Well, I was thinking, maybe an enemy attack is not in progress?

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: And if that were true?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: But then, sir, why have you issued the order: Wing attack, Plan-R?

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Because I thought it proper, Major.  Why else would you think I'd do it?

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Suppose that were the case?

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: But -- why...that would be an awful thing to do, sir.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Perhaps, Major.  Perhaps.  Pour me a scotch and soda, please.  And help yourself to whatever you like.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: Don't fret about it, Major.  There's nothing anyone can do about it now.  I'm the only one who knows the three-letter code group for the CRM-114.

turns.speaker: MAJOR MANDRAKE
turns.text: I know that, sir.

turns.speaker: GENERAL RIPPER
turns.text: We've come a long way since World War II, Major.  And the lessons we've learned are all in Plan-R.
